string: Masks were an integral part of the Sala Mpasu mongongo, or warriors’ society, whose primary task was to protect this small enclave in present-day Democratic Republic of the Congo, against invasions by outside kingdoms. Boys were initiated as junior members into the mongongo after completing a year of education in which they lived with their cohort in the forest, isolated from the rest of their community.

As members rose through the society’s ranks they could earn the right to wear a mask, which demonstrated their economic status and authority within the community. Earning the right to wear a mask involved making payments of livestock, drink, and other material goods to the members who already had the authority to wear the masks.

Once a man owned the mask, his peers taught the new member the knowledge associated with it. There are two types of Sala Mpasu masks: the first is made of fiber and is often distinguished with a hat made of cane or feathers and a raffia beard. The second is made of wood, characterized by its woven cane balls on top of the head, a broad forehead, and the way it bares menacing, pointed teeth.
Mongongo was disbanded in the 1960s with independence from Belgium and the Sala Mpasu began making masks specifically for the market and for export.

A subset of the wood masks are covered in copper sheets, the meaning of which has changed over time as the copper industry in the region changed. At the time that this mask was made in the 20th century, copper was an important symbol of wealth and authority.

This ceremonial mask, alongside many others, have amply domed, bulging forehead, which extends over a snub nose. The wooden mask is covered in copper sheets and includes a raffia beard. The raffia is likely not original.
This mask has deeply set narrow eyes, the copper lines the eye socket.
The mouth of the mask is rectangular in shape, which is carved open and decorated with two rows of pointed teeth.
